Article.Abstract: BACKGROUND: The major cat allergen Fel d I is composed of two disulfide-linked polypeptide chains, chain 1 (70 amino acid residues) and chain 2 (92 amino acid residues). Reduction and alkylation of Fel d I eliminates almost all antigenic and allergenic activity, and detection of linear epitopes with synthetic peptides is therefore not expected. METHODS: The major cat allergen Fel d I is composed of two disulfide-linked polypeptide chains, chain 1 (70 amino acid residues) and chain 2 (92 amino acid residues). Reduction and alkylation of Fel d I eliminates almost all antigenic and allergenic activity, and detection of linear epitopes with synthetic peptides is therefore not expected.We synthesized synthetic peptides of both chains of about 14 amino acid residues, overlapping by 7 residues. The peptides were coupled to Sepharose (Pharmacia, Uppsala, Sweden) and tested with sera of patients with cat allergy. RESULTS: The major cat allergen Fel d I is composed of two disulfide-linked polypeptide chains, chain 1 (70 amino acid residues) and chain 2 (92 amino acid residues). Reduction and alkylation of Fel d I eliminates almost all antigenic and allergenic activity, and detection of linear epitopes with synthetic peptides is therefore not expected.We synthesized synthetic peptides of both chains of about 14 amino acid residues, overlapping by 7 residues. The peptides were coupled to Sepharose (Pharmacia, Uppsala, Sweden) and tested with sera of patients with cat allergy.Three peptides showed specific binding of human IgE, residues 25-38 and 46-59 of chain 1 and residue 15-28 of chain 2. IgE binding was inhibited by Fel d I and the corresponding peptide. Of 61 patients with cat allergy tested, 65% showed IgE binding to at least one of the peptides; 46% showed IgE binding to peptide 25-38, 11% to peptide 46-59, and 28% to peptide 15-28. Each peptide was recognized by only one of the 78 patients with negative RAST results. By affinity chromatography with peptide-Sepharose anti-Fel d I antibodies were isolated, also confirming the specificity of IgE binding to the peptides. The percentage of IgE antibodies against Fel d I reactive with the peptides varied with the serum and the peptide-Sepharose used and ranged from 2% to 55%. CONCLUSIONS: The major cat allergen Fel d I is composed of two disulfide-linked polypeptide chains, chain 1 (70 amino acid residues) and chain 2 (92 amino acid residues). Reduction and alkylation of Fel d I eliminates almost all antigenic and allergenic activity, and detection of linear epitopes with synthetic peptides is therefore not expected.We synthesized synthetic peptides of both chains of about 14 amino acid residues, overlapping by 7 residues. The peptides were coupled to Sepharose (Pharmacia, Uppsala, Sweden) and tested with sera of patients with cat allergy.Three peptides showed specific binding of human IgE, residues 25-38 and 46-59 of chain 1 and residue 15-28 of chain 2. IgE binding was inhibited by Fel d I and the corresponding peptide. Of 61 patients with cat allergy tested, 65% showed IgE binding to at least one of the peptides; 46% showed IgE binding to peptide 25-38, 11% to peptide 46-59, and 28% to peptide 15-28. Each peptide was recognized by only one of the 78 patients with negative RAST results. By affinity chromatography with peptide-Sepharose anti-Fel d I antibodies were isolated, also confirming the specificity of IgE binding to the peptides. The percentage of IgE antibodies against Fel d I reactive with the peptides varied with the serum and the peptide-Sepharose used and ranged from 2% to 55%.Because the affinity of IgE binding to the peptides was very low and only serum samples with high titers of Fel d I-specific IgE antibodies (RAST 4+/5+) showed significant binding, these peptides are not suitable for diagnostic purposes. However, the peptides are useful tools for comparing IgE and ...
Article.ArticleTitle: IgE epitopes on the cat (Felis domesticus) major allergen Fel d I: a study with overlapping synthetic peptides.
Article.Affiliations: Central Laboratory of The Netherlands Red Cross Blood Transfusion Service, Amsterdam.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Allergens;Epitopes;Glycoproteins;Peptide Fragments;Immunoglobulin E;Fel d 1 protein, Felis domesticus
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Allergens(immunology); Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Cats(immunology); Chromatography, Affinity; Epitopes; Glycoproteins(genetics; immunology); Humans; Hypersensitivity(immunology); Immunoglobulin E(immunology); Molecular Sequence Data; Peptide Fragments(chemical synthesis; genetics; immunology); Peptide Mapping; Radioallergosorbent Test
Article.Comments: Data originally imported from the Database of Functional Molecular Immunology, FIMM (http://sdmc.lit.org.sg:8080/fimm/)

Journal.Title: The Journal of allergy and clinical immunology

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Data originally imported from the Database of Functional Molecular Immunology, FIMM (http://sdmc.lit.org.sg:8080/fimm/) and recurated. The following refers to the epitope id as found in the original FIMM database: P001838.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Serum samples were obtained from patients with cat allergy and with IgE antibodies to cat dander.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific serum IgE from cat allergic patients, affinity-purified on the epitope coupled to Sepharose, bound to Fel d I. It did not bind to mite extract containing Der p II. The epitope was synthesized with an additional C-terminal lysine residues for coupling to Sepharose.

Antigen.AntigenReferenceName: Major allergen I polypeptide chain 1 (Fel d I)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Serum samples were obtained from patients with cat allergy and with IgE antibodies to cat dander.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Serum IgE from 28 of 61 (46%) cat allergic patients reacted with the epitope coupled to Sepharose. Only one of 78 cat dander RAST-negative sera reacted. The epitope was synthesized with an additional C-terminal lysine residues for coupling to Sepharose.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Serum samples were obtained from patients with cat allergy and with IgE antibodies to cat dander.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope inhibited binding to the epitope by serum IgE from cat allergic patients. The epitope was synthesized with an additional C-terminal lysine residues for coupling to Sepharose.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Serum samples were obtained from patients with cat allergy and with IgE antibodies to cat dander.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Preincubation of cat-allergic patient serum IgE with cat dander extract, affinity-purified Fel d I, or reduced and alkylated Fel d I inhibited binding to the epitope in a dose-dependent manner. The epitope was synthesized with an additional C-terminal lysine residues for coupling to Sepharose.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Data originally imported from the Database of Functional Molecular Immunology, FIMM (http://sdmc.lit.org.sg:8080/fimm/) and recurated. The sequence in Table 1 is FAVANGNELLLDCS; C at position 13 seems to be a typing error. The following refers to the epitope id as found in the original FIMM database: P001840.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Serum samples were obtained from patients with no cat allergy and with negative RAST to cat dander.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Serum IgE from cat dander RAST-negative sera reacted with the epitope coupled to Sepharose. The epitope was synthesized with an additional C-terminal lysine residues for coupling to Sepharose. The authors conclude that reactivity to the epitope is not specific for cat-allergic sera.
